title: Are Google whiteboard problems the toughest in the tech world? - Quora

response.answer_text: Thanks for the ATA! There has been a big gap throughout my career about how well I think I’m doing at whiteboard coding tests and how well I actually do, as judged by the outcome. It is a task at which I feel I do well—even very well—but the outcome (whether I get a job offer) is usually not positive. Most of the better jobs I’ve had in my career have been ones where the whiteboard coding test was waived completely because my background was deemed strong enough to not require such a test. Indeed, there is probably no other activity I’ve done in my life where the gap between how I think I’m performing and how I actually am performing has been as great. Most things I life I’m good at, I know I’m good at—and most things I suck at, I know I suck at. But with whiteboard coding tests I always feel like I’m doing very well, but it doesn’t lead to an offer. The toughest two whiteboard coding tests I’ve ever had have also been the only ones that have ever led to an offer. They were for small startups, not giants like Google. I believe they pushed me harder because they were serious about hiring me, and they wanted to truly establish the limits of my ability. By contrast, I didn’t find the problems posed in my Google interview especially challenging. But it didn’t lead to an offer.

Finance and physics companies tend to have tougher interview processes than Google’s interview process. Whiteboard interviewers fail to test the following: (1) Mathematical knowledge needed for scientific software, e.g. quantum simulations. (2) Advanced C++, e.g. SFINAE to get round“no overloading by return type only” amongst other “C++ Committee” type knowledge. (3) Data structures/algorithms not in the CS textbook, e.g. double-hashing to obtain a data structure with the benefits of std::map and std::unordered_map, i.e. data is sorted, but in O(n) instead of O(n log n), and lookup is O(1) and collisionless. (4) Rigorous design and testing skills, because whiteboard code is cowboy-code. This type of knowledge is the result of having to use C++ for a very long time to solve a variety of problems, many of them involving advanced maths, and having to write safety-critical code. It can only be demonstrated through code samples containing advanced techniques. It cannot be demonstrated in whiteboard interviews that are designed to test entry-level C++ and entry-level CS. This is why I believe this type of interview is designed to facilitate ageism. If companies want to see how advanced a candidate’s knowledge is then it makes more sense to request code samples with this advanced knowledge or set offline problems that allow advanced knowledge to be demonstrated in the solution sent back. I have also noticed that companies like Sun Microsystems tested general problem-solving skills and the work was interesting simulation work, whereas companies like Microsoft tested entry-level coding and CS skills and the work was menial. I attribute this to IT companies wanting entry-level H-1B workers and tailoring the interviews toward entry-level skills.

I’ve seen many people claim that Google’s technical interviews are more difficult than those of Facebook, Amazon, and Microsoft. Thus, among the most famous tech companies, Google has the hardest interviews. However, there are many less famous tech companies that have harder interviews. For example, MemSQL’s questions are considered to be among the hardest in the industry (see here and here). imo.im is another company with difficult questions. These questions can be at a similar difficulty level to those found on serious contests such as Codeforces and ACM-ICPC regionals, whereas the problems asked by Google usually do not approach that difficulty level.

By whiteboard problems I presume you mean questions asked during an interview. And in that case no, they’re relatively easy in the space of all tech problems. The questions asked during an interview are usually structured to be solvable in <45 min (the length of a typical google interview) and generally have well known approaches that will at least get you a large portion of the way to an answer. They’re set up this way because you want a semi-solved problem so you can evaluate the candidate’s answer, and because the time to evaluate the candidate is limited. On the other hand, the problems you work on once you’re hired haven’t necessarily been solved before, can take much longer, and can require much more space than a single whiteboard to write out. There are at least occasionally real problems that are much harder than the toughest “whiteboard” problem you will see.

Honestly, probably not. At this point, there is likely a negligible difference in toughness between the technical interviews at Google and other similar companies. No matter if you’re interviewing at Google or a smaller startup, the best way to succeed in these interviews is to prepare by practicing the types of questions you will see. For entry level or new grad software engineering positions, you are mainly going to see data structures and algorithms. We’ve compiled a list of over 90 software engineer interview questions you can practice and you can find even more on Leetcode. The best advice would be to practice these problems so that you can feel comfortable and confident in your interviews. That being said, make sure that you take your time when you are answering the questions. Even if the question looks like one you have practiced, we don’t recommend saying this to the interviewer because it might be slightly different. If you don’t look carefully and then you solve it incorrectly or without a completely optimized solution, after telling them you have seen it before, it will hurt your chances of moving forward. So, practice as much as you can, but still take your time and read the questions completely when you are in the actual interview.

No, Google is at the harder end of the standard big name companies but that is all. You get harder questions at smaller more niche companies where the niche involves mathematics. Financial tech companies are an example, but just academic or research type companies generally. I’ve gone on interviews where they wanted me to basically come up with a result that an academic paper is about as an interview question. Now maybe the idea was to just see how close I would come, etc., but you get the idea.

I have been lucky to get offers from Google, Amazon just this year. Google interviews no doubt are least predictable and the hardest for software engineering role. My interview questions seemed new to me and were not directly picked up from Leetcode and similar websites. I believe if you have built good depth on the data structures and algorithms and have practiced on how to go about solving any problem then you don’t need to worry much. The general expectation is to cover 2 data structure problems in 45/60 min coding round and 1 design problem in the system design round. You need to practice on developing good technical depth, problem solving skills and understand the interview pattern. Some resources I found super helpful for my preparation includes Leetcode (real interview questions), Glassdoor(overall interview loop, salary ranges, negotiation), ExpertMitra(mock interview).

No. The whiteboard problems are typically pretty easy. What is tough about Google interviews is the evaluation standards, not the questions themselves. The interviewer is looking for much more than just a solution; they're looking for an approach to the solution and a communication style, and more.

The Actual Intention Or Why to solve the problem with whiteboard : It's like how you solve something If you have only a pen and paper or pen and whiteboard? Another way : It's like how you solve in steps or in a way of doing things or solving in paper before jumping to do the actual or how is your mind works when you receive a problem. It's not hard or easy, Its all about mindset, Do you have such a mindset? If you mix that mindset with tech-stuff a bit

Very much depends on the interviewer and the position. In a Google interview, one of my friends asked to write a dijkstra on an undirecred graph with both negative and positive weights. The question doesn't have answer. So it's not called tough, it's dumb. In another company he were asked to solve a problem which the optimal solution Would be achieved via implementing a Patricia tree. I've seen many really hard questions from high tech companies which were sometime harder than google.

I certainly hope not. As a frequent interviewer I specifically aim to pitch questions that a reasonably skilled software engineer should be able to accomplish in a 45 minute interview. If I aim for a question with an Aha insight, I am likely to learn basically nothing about the person who I am supposed to be evaluating, as well as contributing to a really unpleasant encounter for both of us.

There’s a finite set of problems that can be asked in an interview reasonably and everyone in the industry tends to choose from that pool. This is sort of a problem, because candidates can memorize the answers, or the approaches, and then what are you measuring excactly? Palantir supposedly asks real head scratchers, but they want pretty severe data scientist types so that may be natural.

In my experience(2 on-sites, 10 years apart), they are no harder than elsewhere. They tend to push you all the way to the end as opposed to cutting it short and saying”ok, that’s enough, I can see you’ve got it”.

No. The hardest ones are given by sadistic nerds who suddenly found themselves in charge, who are tech savvy, but not burdened by human emotions or knowledge outside their field of interest… they have little interest in a new hire besides to prove that his metaphorical dick is bigger.

I doubt it. Unless your work is bound to whiteboards, as in, you are like TV scientist that works his/hers problems on whiteboard instead of using a computer, then all whiteboard interviews are absolutely useless and damaging.
Anyone can ask tough questions. The trick is to ask one that is easy enough to complete in 45–60 minutes and get to the interesting bits before time runs out.
Employment qualification testing mainly gives HR an excuse not to hire someone and avoid legalities. Perhaps they don’t like your shoes.
